title: Is abortion morally justified under utilitarianism? - Quora

response.answer_text: Utilitarianism is (in short) the premise that that which does the most good to the most people while doing the least harm to the fewest people has a strong tendency to be good. It’s degree of “goodness” will be directly proportional to the quantity and quality of benefit vs. the quantity and quality of harm. In short: More people helped and the degree to which you help them determines how “good” a thing is. When you say “abortion”, you are painting with a broad brush. If we go off of the western European model of what is appropriate in abortion, then killing a fetus before 18 weeks is perfectly fine because it’s not a person. It is the epitome of a utilitarian equation — no person is harmed, one person benefits. It’s good. Utilitarianism if followed slavishly breaks down. I consider myself to be something along the lines of a soft-utilitarian. I don’t think you can adequately analyze every moral dilemma with a single school of thought on morality. A lot of how we determine good vs. evil has an implicit “time” component in it. How much time you have to act and solicit aid is always going to determine which school of thought is best in a given moment. If you are careening towards a crowd and (to move along with this tired analogy) and can choose a fork in the road: hit a single child vs. hit 10 people in the crowd and you only have seconds to think, it’s clearly the right choice to veer left (oh and the child is on the left). But along with a “time” component, there’s a “choice” component. How much of a choice do you have in the course of events? See, this is where utilitarianism breaks down: what if you only have to push the child in front of the car to stop it from hitting the crowd? Very different course of action. A purist of utilitarian thought would say, “Then it’s good.” But we know better. There’s simply more to it than that. See: Specifically what characteristics of a healthy human fetus lead some pro-choice people to claim that it is neither alive nor human?What is the response to the argument from fetal potential in the abortion debate?The pregnancy, having become a reality, confines the choices. The fetus before 18 weeks is not a person, and so any abortion for any reason before that time, I don’t consider to be much in any doubt. After that, I leave it to the local government to make policy based on the values of their citizens. I’d prefer it to be left as legal as possible based on the needs of the mother.

It depends. Utilitarianism dictates that a thing is ethical if it secures a beneficial outcome. To say whether or not abortion is justified under utilitarian ethics depends on whether the fetus would have had an overall positive or negative impact on the world had they been allowed to develop, be born, and live. Utilitarian ethics would say it is unethical to abort any pregnancy which would result in a person who has a positive overall impact on the world. The flip side is that it would also say that it is unethical to not abort a pregnancy which would result in a person who has a negative overall impact. Of course, it is impossible to determine a person’s overall impact on the world, especially prior to their birth. There are far too many variables and potentialities to be considered. Utilitarianism is a very poor guide for such issues unless you impose limits upon its scope, limits which would ultimately boil down to it becoming a matter of self determination.
